Award.AwardTitle: Multispectral Airglow Observations of Gravity Waves during the August 2017 Total Solar Eclipse
Award.AbstractNarration: During a solar eclipse, when the Moon passes between the Earth and the Sun, the shadow results in cooling of the Earth's atmosphere along the swath that experiences a total eclipse. It has long been hypothesized that internal gravity waves (GWs) would be generated in response to sudden horizontal temperature gradients, that would then propagate away from the region of the shadow. The PI, who is an early career female, will deploy two imaging spectrographs at separate locations along the line of totality that will observe airglow before, during, and after the North American total solar eclipse on August 21, 2017. A third imager will be located far away from the eclipsed area, to provide a control dataset. The science objective is to study eclipse-driven gravity wave evolution in the airglow. This experiment is expected to provide information about how the atmosphere reacts to fast changes in ozone heating and ionizing photon flux. The work will also contribute to the debate about where gravity waves form and propagate during a solar eclipse.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research project was to take observations of the upper atmosphere during the total solar eclipse in 2017, and study its effects on the atmosphere and wave formation. During a total solar eclipse, the moon blocks all of the sun's light from reaching the part of Earth in the moon's shadow. This creates "nighttime-like" conditions in the atmosphere over a very short time, much more quickly than during a typical sunset. This rapid change in conditions can cause changes in the atmosphere, turbulence, and waves which can be observed with instruments from the ground.

We deployed two ground-based instruments to observe light from the atmosphere along the path of totality during the total solar eclipse in August 2017. This light is emitted by atoms in the atmosphere, and changes in the brightness of light at specific wavelengths can tell us about what is happening at certain altitudes. During the night following the eclipse, we observed perturbations in brightness at two of these wavelengths. This indicates wave activity in the atmosphere. We compared our observations to other data, and used a computer model to understand the effects of the geomagnetic conditions and the total solar eclipse on the atmosphere.

Training the next generation of observational space scientists is of the utmost importance. This research and observational campaign provided hands-on learning for graduate students who took the instrument to Carbondale, IL during the eclipse. One of the graduate students is analyzing this data as part of his PhD dissertation. An early career scientist served as the principle investigator for this work. As PI of this research project, she added to the underrepresented group of women leading and participating in current, important science research.
